comments.commentBody:
President Obama’s rejection of a reporter’s question today raises interesting considerations.

I’m all for freedom of the press and I read lots of it but I can’t help to think of certain minions of Clear Channel whose motive is (not seldom) the extraction of a sensationalist sound bite with which to spin heads on talk shows and to inflame a dizzied and beleaguerd audience of underwhelmed news vultures.I’m sure that often a subject ‘of interest’ feels like the fox in a hunt, surrounded by baying dogs. I say, go after the “watergates’hammer and tong but the constant drilling for news just for the sake of programming, well that’s an abuse of the system and one shouldn’t feel obligated to oblige that.

There are certainly many who reach or aspire to the gravity of the true purpose and potential of responsible journalism. Take the writings of a political figure like Nobel Peace Price winner Aung San Suu Kyi of Myanmar, who published many essays in Japanese newspapers and elsewhere. People like her, who make statements such as this in her famous 'Freedom From Fear' speech: "It is not power that corrupts but fear. Fear of losing power corrupts those who wield it and fear of the scourge of power corrupts those who are subject to it." That’s a sound bite worth reading. Especially since she backs it up by overcoming that corrupting fear with her own life. It's not just a job.

The public deserves access to its governmental representatives through responsible journalism. But when so much of news today resembles a Jerry Springer free-for-all sometimes you feel like you're the 'mark' of news dealers who supply the junkies with bad street grade 'non news'. Who can blame someone for needing a break from that?

Sometimes it would seen that it’s actually more responsible to slam the door in order to marshall your energies more effectively than reflexively and constantly feeding the ‘dog of blog’ -the news that never sleeps and its arterial feeds --- When they say : "On Balance" news...they often mean....balanced on the almighty dollar--dollars milks from a a gov't official's precious time.....money Clear Channel invests in Wall Street.….for instance.

Give a guy a break once in a while…
Finally, anyone who is interviewed knows the frustration of being melded in print, or out of context, into a reporter’s slanted agenda; an agenda set by the Big Boss for big ratings at the media hive, That’s dumb. It’s frustrating and a waste of our time.

I find the description "warm" somewhat puzzling. A few years ago, my husband and I had the "pleasure" of bumping into Dean Kagan at a well-known Harvard Square chocolate shop (it is known for its chocolate "mice"--Burdick or something??) . It was a rainy Sunday afternoon, and our Harvard Law School reunion had just wrapped up that morning. We said "hello" to Dean Kagan and mentioned that we had a great time at the reunion (the first one we had attended), and she basically brushed us off without a smile (forced or otherwise), or even a mumbled pleasantry!!

Perhaps she was having a bad day, or just wanted to have her hot chocolate in peace, but are those the kind of people skills she is being touted for? My God, for all she knew, we were substantial donors (past or potential)! Needless, our contributions to the Law School ended then and there, and did not resume until the new Dean (a very down to earth Martha Minow) was named several months ago.
Larry in Arkansas: obviously humor is not your cup of coffee. Have a nice day and I certainly hope Mr. Pistole is approved but I'm still going to stay tuned.

Correction: previous post incomplete:

Certainly Daniel Pearl was a sterling example of courageous journalism.
It is also possible that Mrs. Pearl was protected from having her beautiful moment of tribute hijacked for soundbites.

______________
** Along with mention of Clear Channel, these should be included:
Newport, General Electric, Westinghouse, Newport, Viacom, Disney, Time Warner, Rupert Murdoch and ETC.

Check this for : Who ‘owns’the news: (and what for)
http://la.indymedia.org...

"I guess it's OK to break the law as long as you're related to the right people."

Now you are getting the hang of the world of the good ole boys.

It amazes me that those GOP spit bucket carriers, never have a comment on an article such as this one?????

Where are you Proffy, Jacobi, Leah????? Which one of you will explain the GOP plan to better our country's future? There is none, is there? Just complain, obstruct, reject, lie, distort and confuse - That's the strategy, isn't it?

I know, the strategy is lower taxes, less Gubment, family values, lets throw in a constitional ammendmetn to ban gay marriage.

How's that immigration issue working for you? That Limbaugh leadership, how's that working?

For all the liberal apologists on here: What about Africans who try to claim asylum here because they're homosexual and end up getting denied? I'm sure they are at way higher risk in Kenya than Obama's aunt. As far as I know all his other relatives in Kenya are doing fine.

Most of those running for office are of the same breed. I can only hope those who are a supported by  the Tea Party are elected. That is not to say I agree with all the tea party's views I just want a message sent to DC that America is not a socialist government and to stop the advancement of the liberal agenda of hating America.

It has a bad smell of politics; President Obama's first two picks for a sensitive airport screening leader. It is obvious the first two picks withdrew because of personal reasons of unethical conduct. It begs the question...why Mr. Obama, a man of moral judgments upon others, targeting people that do not fit into his mode of governance, would overlook the character flaws of his first two picks, and letting the TSA without a leader, for the complete time of his presidency.

It is a telling sign of President Obama's priorities...obviously airport security is not high on his list.

Mr. Pistole's experience and background it seems, would put him on top of Obama's list, well ahead of the two drop-outs. With all of the accolades imposed on Mr. Obama by his supporters...this incident of his presidential wisdom or his moral capacity to lead, comes into question.

There is no doubt, that our young president is being monitored by a majority of Americans. This airport security issue is but one of President Obama's many controversial moves, or lack of moves, that voters in November will give serious thought, of voting for the party of Obama.

Indeed, a referendum on Mr. Obama's presidency.
He got a job in the reserve to avoid actually going to Vietnam then acts like a military hero.  Sounds like Bush.

This guy is a typical lying politician.  As one who really did serve I cannot imagine that he let these misrepresentations stand by accident.  Of course now that it is no longer convenient to let the lies fester he will use some of his politician/lawyer training to weasel out of the situation.  Just one more example of why people are so upset with government.

This is the same Raymond Hernandez who keeps calling Joe Lieberman a "centrist" and a "moderate". Sounds as though this story was planted with Hernandez.

Let's see Mr. Hernandez follow up on former Connecticut congressman Chris Shays's statements over the past two decades that, he "didn't enter the military; he served in the Peace Corps." The problem is that Peace Corps service was never considered the basis for either an exemption or a deferment from the draft. Shays received a very low lottery number in December 1969 which should have insured that he was drafted. Yet somehow Shays got out of the draft at the height of the Vietnam War. And then three years later he claimed conscientious objector status.

Why didn't the New York Times ever fact-check Shays' false claims that his Peace Corps service got him out of the military?

I'm a democrat through and through.
Dump this liar. period.
The more I think about it, Why don't you call me for the real truth........over

I have no problem with his not serving in Viet Nam,I did but many of my friends did not.I'm neither proud nor ashamed of having served there. I do have a problem with people who lie about it to get ahead,especially some guy my age who was born with a silver spoon in his mouth,didn't get dirty and will never deal with the consequences of it.I wouldn't vote for a Republican,we have different agendas,but I wouldn't vote for this guy either.

I lived in CT for a number of years. Richard Blumenthal is a brilliant and highly effective attorney general. It is a shame he is resorting to misrepresenting his military record in order to win votes. I say this as a liberal democrat. It was wrong when George W. Bush did it, and it is wrong that Richard Blumenthal has done it as well.

Al Gore served 6 months in Viet Nam andwas a "Remington Raider" for those 6 months. He was not a decorated hero as someone in this post implied. There are plenty of right wingers who avoided the draft and serving in Viet Nam starting with Rush Limbaugh, Michael Savage. Michael Reagan and so on. It's disgraceful that people like this play the war hero or beat the war drums to gain personal advantage. Two tours in VN 65 and 68 and proud of it.VMA Alumni.

It's a shame this man claims to have served in Nam. If this is the kind of character he has he does not belong in government. There are too many dishonest people in government and that includes the president.
These kind of people seek the glory and praise that is reserved to thoes who did serve and suffer. As a marine vet I condemn this man.

As a matter of conscience, I was against the war in Vietnam.  Early on, I gave up my student deferment because I thought, correctly I believe, that student deferments were being used by upper middle and upper income kids to avoid serving while less well off white, black, and brown kids were serving and dying.  I fought the draft.  That was hard and it altered the course of my life forever.  But it did not cost me my life or leave me with the horrific memories of those who fought and I have always felt a sorrow and sympathy for those who served.  They gave a part of themselves and I respect that.  It is still not "politically correct" to admit you were a C.O., but as a matter of principle you have to be honest.  The men who duck the issue, who were against the war as a matter of conscience and now avoid the issue bother me.  The men who ducked the war and now pretend they served have my contempt.  They do not deserve the respect of those who supported or opposed the war.  They certainly should not be a U.S. senator.

This guy lies and when the lie is discovered he claims he "misspoke".  Only a politician would have the audacity to attempt to explain an outright lie by claiming he misspoke.  He should be removed as AG!

Unfortunately Richard Blumenthal, the Attorney General from Connecticut, appears typical of the majority of political office holders who believe themselves superior to the populace, revel in their power, provide  little public service, and milk the public payroll for themselves and their associates.

A good old ski buddy of mine who was a Marine, but never got assigned Vietnam service, always enjoys telling about the guys who say they were "door gunners" when pressed about what they did.  Interesting.
I'm a democrat and I don't want this liar elected. I would like to think we could do better than this clown. What a disgrace.
So he is run out of politics, what does he care? With his connections and amoral nature, I expect that that he will find a vice president's position waiting for him at Goldman Sachs in no time flat.

OK Ross, OK Ralph, now, examine this passage very, very closely.

Was John Kerry in Cambodia during Christmas of 1968?

One of the things John Kerry has talked and written about for a long time was what he described as his "illegally" being ordered to enter Cambodia.
In a letter to the editor of the Boston Herald in October, 1979, Kerry wrote, "I remember spending Christmas Eve of 1968 five miles across the Cambodian border being shot at by our South Vietnamese allies who were drunk and celebrating Christmas. The absurdity of almost being killed by our own allies in a country in which President Nixon claimed there were no American troops was very real."
He also made reference to the Cambodia-Christmas story during remarks on the floor of the Senate in 1986.
He said the memory was "seared" in him.
Kerry said his "deep mistrust" of U.S. government statements began when he was in Cambodia at Christmas listened to President Richard Nixon claim that no American troops were there.

Once again...

Kerry said his "deep mistrust" of U.S. government statements began when he was in Cambodia at Christmas listened to President Richard Nixon claim that no American troops were there.
He said the memory was "seared" in him.

Now, WHO was president during Christmas 1968 ???

That's right, LBJ.

Kerry is as much a liar as Blumenthal.
